node.html:
In a previous post I dived into the Danish Ministry of Educations school initiative to lift the students with the poorest academic performances. The point made in the post were that the evaluation of the schools relied on so little data, that the payouts would be a lottery. A couple of months ago the result and payout for each school was announced for the first year of the initiative. The ministry claims that 400 students improved their performance as a result of the initiative 1.

The Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR) had gained access to documents detailing the performance for this year and the three previous years. I asked them to share their data to have a closer look. It turned out that not only had the ministry not accounted for regression towards the mean, they also only included schools who actually improved not all schools in the initiative and they used a regular mean where a weighted mean should have been applied. With these errors the true number of students improved as a result of the initiative is closer to 200 than 400.

1 The Ministry of Education: 62 skoler får penge fra skolepuljen
